instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message: I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that has minor liquid damage on the <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>/<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> side of the board. I was getting only 5v on the charger and 450ma, which is high. I replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, but still had 5v 450ma. I checked the board on thermal, and saw <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> was getting hot. Replaced <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and got 20v, but all my AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages were pulsing. Checked on thermal again and saw <CHIP>U7660</CHIP> was getting warm. Replaced <CHIP>U7660</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and now I have steady voltages on all my rails up until S5. I am missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>. I tried T2 firmware restore and it is recognized in DFU mode, but quickly fails and produces an error. Does this mean the PCH is at fault, or is there something else I should check first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message:
If <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> was burnt, I bet SSD is damaged.
T2 cannot access its partition and will never complete DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message: I checked diode mode to ground on all the SSD rails and they all match against my working board, so not convinced its a SSD issue. My previous post was incorrect when I said I have steady voltages up until S5. I now noticed that all my AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages still pulse, but they stay steady for about 20 seconds and then pulse, so I was not holding my probe there long enough to catch the pulse. PPBUS is 12.6v for 20 seconds or so, and then drops to 12.3v for about 2-3 seconds and then goes back to 12.6v. No pulse on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, but <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> is 5.13v and the pulses down to 5.02v when PPBUS drops. I cannot find any shorts or anything heating up abnormally on thermal, so not sure where to check next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message:
If AWAKE and SLPS2R voltage are not stable, that's the reason T2 cannot complete DFU.

When <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> drops, what happens with <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>USB_C</SIGNAL> meter shows steady 20V at same time?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> stays steady at 3.3v the whole time and the meter shows 20v still but the amps do drop down at little when PPBUS drops.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message:
12.6V is the nominal <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
If drops to 12.3V means SMC lose the communication with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> somehow.
There can be an issue with battery bus.
I recommend to test with known good battery; not new chinese one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message: I tried with a known good battery and PPBUS pulses from 11.6v to 12.3v, with the charger connected. Without the charger and just the battery connected, PPBUS seems to be steady 11.2v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message:
Check voltage and diode mode on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.
Try changing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, if possible.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message: Diode mode values seem to match another board. With both battery and charger connected, <SIGNAL>SMBUS_3V3_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL> is 3.3v, but pulses down to 3.2v. <SIGNAL>SMBUS_3V3_BATT_SDA</SIGNAL> is 3.3v, but pulses down to about 2.7v. With just the battery connected, they both seem to be steady 3.3v. I can try and replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and report back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message: I changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, but still the same issue

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing S5 rails
threads.message:
Seems to have communication on the battery bus, as you've noted pulsing down; you can check it with o-scope.
If battery and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> are good, there remains T2 as suspect.
